title: Investigating the role of attention in reading
abstract: Reading is undoubtedly one of the most important cognitive skills in modern societies; yet, despite decades of reading research, some critical issues remain poorly understood. Given that the reading process is cognitively multi-faceted (involving linguistic processing, oculo-motor processing, memory and attention), getting to understand the reading process in full is by definition an interdisciplinary endeavour.   Therefore, striking an interdisciplinary alliance between the fields of reading and attention, this project's mission is to increase understanding of the role of attention in reading (ROAR). Specifically, this project aims to answer the question of how attention is distributed across the visual field during reading, and how attention is used to organize incoming linguistic information. Moreover, this project offers a novel attention-based perspective on reading problems and dyslexia, along with a practical application to help remedy such problems. In short, getting to grips with how attention operates in reading may be key to solving several long-standing questions.   This project comprises state-of-the-art electro-encephalography and eye-tracking techniques that will provide novel means to investigate attention in reading. Moreover, a recently developed reading interface, geared at facilitating word recognition by reducing interference from surrounding words, will be upgraded and tested with dyslexic readers. Thus, this project is perfectly placed in the Goldilocks zone between fundamental research and practical applicability.

motivations: Despite decades of research, the reading process remains poorly understood, particularly the role of attention in reading.
Reading problems and dyslexia persist, and a deeper understanding of attention's role in reading could help address these issues.
objectives: Investigate how attention is distributed across the visual field during reading.
Examine how attention is used to organize incoming linguistic information during reading.
Develop a novel attention-based perspective on reading problems and dyslexia, and create a practical application to help remedy these issues.
methods: Utilize state-of-the-art electro-encephalography and eye-tracking techniques to investigate attention in reading.
Upgrade and test a reading interface designed to facilitate word recognition by reducing interference from surrounding words, specifically with dyslexic readers.
results: Gain a deeper understanding of the role of attention in reading, shedding light on long-standing questions in the field.
Develop a practical application to help remedy reading problems and dyslexia, improving reading abilities for individuals with these challenges.
